title: Melcior Juncà
text:
Melcior Juncà i Farré (<a href="Sant%20Joan%20de%20les%20Abadesses">Sant Joan de les Abadesses</a>, <a href="Ripoll%C3%A8s">Ripollès</a>, 1757 - <a href="Tarragona">Tarragona</a>, 1824) was a Catalan "<a href="maestro%20de%20capilla">maestro de capilla</a>," composer and music theorist. He was son of a musician, Jacinto Juncà. From 1798 to 1806 he was chapel master at the <a href="Cathedral%20of%20Tarragona">Cathedral of Tarragona</a>. His treatise "La Melopea desconocida" describes a method based on speculative and practical division of the octave into twenty-four parts.
Works, editions, recordings.
His output is primarily of religious music in <a href="Latin">Latin</a>; <a href="Mass%20%28music%29">Mass</a>es, <a href="antiphons">antiphons</a>, <a href="regret%20%28emotion%29">regret</a>s <a href="motet">motet</a>s; and vernacular Spanish <a href="songs">songs</a>, "<a href="tono%20%28music%29">tono</a>s", and <a href="villancicos">villancicos</a>. His motet "Beata mater" was recorded in 2007.
